Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 For repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan failed to achieve
compliance.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MiSEP and
your contract.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the local office at (616)552-3662.

ALLEGATION:
Staff invaded a resident’s personal space by touching her hair and shoulders in a
mocking way. Resident asked staff to stop. Staff grounded resident because she
wanted to call her mentor. There is a concern staff being physically aggressive and
verbally abusive.
INVESTIGATION:
Interviews
On 11/13/2020 I interviewed Staff 2 and Staff 3 by phone. Staff 2 reported that she
was working at the time of the incident but was in the staff office and did not see the
incident. Staff 3 reported that she was helping a resident work on a puzzle when she
heard Staff 1 and Resident A talking to one another in the hallway. Staff 3 reported
that she heard Resident A say, “leave me alone,” but she thought they were just
joking around and playing with one another because Resident A plays around a lot
with staff. Staff 3 stated that she had her back to them for most of the interaction, so
she didn’t see much. When she did turn to face them, Resident A was saying “stop
touching me” to Staff 1, but Resident A was not near Staff 1 at that time.
3

On 11/13/2020 I interviewed Residents A, B, C, D, E, F, G, and H via TEAMS due to
a pending Covid-19 test. Resident A reported that she returned to the home after
work and asked Staff 1 if she could take her shower last because her hair takes
longer to wash than the other girls. Staff 1 told her that she had to go first, so
Resident A told her that she might take longer than she was allowed. Staff 1 then
told her she would get grounded if she took too long. Resident A stated that she
came out of the bathroom within her allotted time and Staff 1 started waving her
hands in Resident A’s face saying, “see, you had enough time.” Resident A stated
that she is triggered by people touching her without permission and she became
upset when Staff 1 started touching her hair and putting her hands in Resident A’s
face. Resident A stated that she asked Staff 1 politely to stop touching her and to
leave her alone, but she didn’t. Resident A stated that Staff 1 was blocking the
doorway, so Resident A pushed Staff 1’s hand away and tried to get around her.
Staff 1 lost her balance, then used both of her hands to push Resident A’s back
causing Resident A to stumble. Resident A stated that she felt that Staff 1 pushed
her because she was taken aback by Resident A hitting her hand. She felt as if Staff
1 was antagonizing her when she knew Resident A was already upset. Resident A
stated that she feels safe in the home and does not feel that Staff 1 was trying to
hurt her.
Residents B, D, G, and H were present in the home and heard the interaction but did
not see what took place. Residents E and F, saw the interaction as described by
Resident A, but did not report that Staff 1 pushed Resident A. Resident C described
the events as reported by Resident A, including seeing Staff 1 use two hands to
push Resident A on the back, as she walked away from Staff 1, causing Resident A
to stumble.
Staff 1 started the interview by stating that she took full responsibility for her actions.
She stated that Resident A wanted to take her shower last, but Staff 1 told her she
had to go first because other residents were doing their jobs. Resident A told her
that she was going to go over her time if she had to go first, so Staff 1 told her there
would be a consequence if she went over her allotted time which would be the same
whether she went first or last. Resident A came out of the shower in time and Staff 1
said, “see, you had plenty of time.“ Resident A laughed and smiled then, but as she
got close to the end of the hall where she could see her peers “a switch flipped” and
she started yelling “leave me alone.” Staff 1 stated that she made a mistake and
“continued to play.” She reported that she extended both of her arms to the sides,
blocking the hallway, at which time Resident A pushed Staff 1’s left shoulder. Staff 1
responded by shoving her hand away playfully. Staff 1 denied ever putting her hands
in Resident A’s face or touching her in any other way.
On 11/13/2020 I interviewed the Home Supervisor by phone. She was not present at
the time of the incident, but Staff 1 told her that she was “playing” with Resident A
and, when Resident A hit Staff 1’s hand away from her, Staff 1 “playfully” pushed
Resident A on her back. Staff 1 admitted to the Home Supervisor that she shouldn’t
have played like that with Resident A.
4

Documents
On 11/12/2020 I received and reviewed Staff 1’s training records, annual
evaluations, and written disciplinary action documents. The only written disciplinary
action provided were as follows:
 Written warning dated 2/11/2019 for an incident on 1/13/2019 during which Staff
1 failed to pass medication despite documenting that the medication had been
passed
 Written warning dated 11/8/2017 regarding overdue training
 Verbal warning dated 5/15/17 for an incident on 3/7/2017 during which Staff A left
a resident unsupervised in a bathroom for 45 minutes.
 Written warning dated 11/2/2015 regarding overdue training.
On 11/12/2020 I received and reviewed an Incident Report (IR) written by the Home
Supervisor on 11/9/2020. The IR documented that on 10/26/2020 Resident A told
Supervisor 1 that on 10/25/2020, Staff 1 “was rude and provoking towards her while
she was in a bad mood, and violated her rights by ‘putting her hands on’ her when
she asked her not to touch her.” Resident A told Supervisor 1 that Staff 1 “gave her
a little shove as she was trying to get past her and that she had asked her more than
one time not to play around with her like that.”
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.158 Discipline.
(2) An institution shall prohibit all cruel and severe
discipline, including any of the following:
(a) Any type of corporal punishment inflicted in any
manner.
ANALYSIS: Staff 1 used inappropriate corporal punishment when she
responded to Resident A pushing her shoulder by either hitting
Resident A’s hand and or/pushing her on the back.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
5

ADDITIONAL FINDINGS:
The staff of the Antonini program did not follow written policies.
INVESTIGATION:
Interviews
On 11/13/2020 I interviewed Staff 3 by phone. Staff 3 reported that, as she was
walking toward the medication room, Resident A asked her to get her a client’s rights
form, and Staff 3 stated she would after she passed medication. Staff 3 stated that
she forgot to get the form. Staff 3 stated that she did not complete an incident report,
but she thinks that Staff 1 did because she was Shift Supervisor that night and the
Shift Supervisor typically completes the forms.
On 11/13/2020 I interviewed Residents A and Staff 1. Resident A reported that after
Resident A hit Staff 1’s hand, Staff 1 stated that she should give Resident A a
consequence of grounding, but she was not going to because Staff 1 was “playing
too much.” Resident A stated that after Resident A asked to call her mentor, Staff 1
said, “you know what, I am going to ground you” and denied Resident A’s request to
call her mentor. Staff 1 confirmed that she did tell Resident A she wasn’t going to
ground her because Staff 1 felt as if she had acted inappropriately causing Resident
A to hit her. Staff 1 stated that she did implement a grounding later, but it was due to
Resident A refusing bedtime expectations and had nothing to do with a call request.
On 11/13/2020 I interviewed the Home Supervisor by phone. The Home Supervisor
stated that Staff 1’s behavior was unprofessional in her interactions with Resident A
as well as her statement to Resident A that she wouldn’t be grounded, yet later the
same evening implemented a grounding. The Home Supervisor stated that no
incident report was completed that night or immediately after the incident being
reported to her.
Documents
On 11/12/2020 I received and reviewed an Incident Report (IR) written by the Home
Supervisor on 11/9/2020. The IR documented that on 10/26/2020 Resident A told
Supervisor 1 about the 10/25/2020 incident.
On 11/17/20 I received and reviewed the facility’s policy regarding written incident
report requirements as well as client concerns/complaint procedure. The Incident
Reporting policy indicates that an electronically written incident report must be
completed within 24 hours of a client rights and or abuse/neglect allegation.
6

On 11/17/20 I received and reviewed the facility’s policy entitle Suitable Treatment
and Freedom of Movement Procedures, which describes inappropriate
responses/involvement of staff members, including:
 Display of hostility. Examples may include speaking in any angry manner or a
way that is “blaming” to the child.
 Aggressive or passive behavior used to have unnecessary control over a
child.
 Demeaning a child. Examples may include talking down to or ridiculing,
teasing, mocking, or taunting a child.
 Horseplay, as it is inappropriate for traumatized children. This includes
tickling.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4109 Program statement.
(1) An institution shall have and follow a current written
program statement which specifically addresses all
of the following:
(C) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission,
care, safety, and supervision, methods for
addressing residents’ needs, implementation of
treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
ANALYSIS: The staff of the Antonini home did not follow written policies by
failing to ensure the availability of client complaint forms, not
completing an incident report within the required timeframes, or
following the staff behavior expectations.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
7

IV. RECOMMENDATION
It is recommended that no change me made to the current license status upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan.
